questions.text: In which of the following type of carcinoma of the breast, is a biopsy of the opposite breast advised? (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Invasive lobular carcinoma is frequently multifocal, multicentric, and bilateral so in these patients we need to do biopsy of the other breast as well and we can not perform breast conservative surgery in these patients.

questions.text: Group of lymph node involved in breast carcinoma are all of the following except: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Pretracheal group of lymphnodes are not involved in breast carcinoma. Supraclavicular, Axillary and Internal mammary group of lymph nodes can be involved in breast carcinoma.

choices.text: Invasion of skin with malignant cells

questions.text: Peau-d-orange is due to: (AIIMS Nov 2015)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Peau-d-orange is due to cutaneous lymphatic edema, where the infltrated skin is tethered by sweat ducts, it can not swell, leading to an appearance like orange skin. •It occurs due to obstruction of subdermal lymphatics (lymphatic permeation by tumor cells) • It is seen in advanced breast cancer (may be seen in chronic abscess)

questions.text: Most common type of breast carcinoma: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Invasive ductal carcinoma of the breast accounts for 80% of breast cancers. Option C can not be the answer as phyllodes tumour is a benign condition in most of the patients.

questions.text: Carcinoma breast is least commonly seen in: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Sequence of occurrence of breast cancer: Upper outer quadrant > Upper inner quadrant > Lower outer quadrant > Lower inner quadrant

questions.text: Nipple inversion occurs due to involvement of:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Retraction of nipple is due to fibrosis in and around Subareolar duct Retraction/dimpling of skin is due to involvement of Cooper’s ligament Peau-D-orange is due to blockage of subdermal lymphatics

questions.text: Triple assessment for CA Breast includes: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Triple assessment is used for the screening and diagnosis of breast carcinoma and consists of clinical examination for the palpable breast lump and axillary lymph nodes. Mammography for detecting the non palpable breast lesions so that they can be detected at an early stage and managed appropriately and FNAC to make a tissue diagnosis.

questions.text: Best diagnostic method for breast lump is: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Best diagnostic method for a breast lump is biopsy, tissue diagnosis is the best method to reach the diagnosis of breast carcinoma. Only role of USG in case of a breast lesion is to differentiate between a solid and a cystic lesion. USG can not make the diagnosis of breast carcinoma. Mammography is useful in detecting non palpable lesions of the breast, depending on the characteristics of the lesion on mammography we can have a rough idea whether the lesion is benign or malignant, but mammography can not give us a definitive diagnosis of breast carcinoma. FNAC is helpful as a screening modality for the breast lump, it can help you differentiate benign from malignant but it can not give you the definitive diagnosis and can not comment on the ER PR and Her2 nue status. FNAC can not distinguish follicular adenoma from follicular carcinoma.

questions.text: A 45-years old woman present with a hard and mobile lump in the breast. Next investigation (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Whenever you start the workup of a breast lesion first investigation is always a radiological investigation in the form of mammography because if you do a needle biopsy or FNAC it hampers the tissue architecture and can hamper the results of mammography. In this particular case even though patient has a palpable mass still you will subject the patient to mammography to rule out any other non palpable lesion in the same or contralateral breast. FNAC can be performed after mammography as a screening test, it can help you differentiate benign from malignant but it can not give you the definitive diagnosis and can not comment on the ER PR and Her2 neu status. FNAC cannot distinguish follicular adenoma from follicular carcinoma. Only role of USG in case of a breast lesion is to differentiate between a solid and a cystic lesion. USG can not make the diagnosis of breast carcinoma. Best diagnostic method for a breast lump is excision biopsy, tissue diagnosis is the best method to reach the diagnosis of breast carcinoma. But we do not go for excision biopsy straight forward

questions.text: Investigation of choice for High risk breast cancer in female is:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) MRI is the investigation of choice for high risk breast cancer like the one who have a familial risk with BRCA gene mutation and those with strong family history of breast carcinoma. The reason being MRI can detect even the early lesions in these patients and help in making the diagnosis at a early stage. Role of PET CT in a patient of breast carcinoma is to look for metastasis and not for diagnosis. Mammography helps as a screening tool in general population and starts at the age of 40 years but it is less sensitive in high risk patients when compared with efficacy of MRI. Only role of USG in case of a breast lesion is to differentiate between a solid and a cystic lesion. USG can not make the diagnosis of breast carcinoma.

questions.text: Most sensitive imaging for ductal carcinoma in situ of breast is: (AIIMS Nov 2014)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Most sensitive imaging for DCIS of breast is MRI. MRI is the investigation of choice for high risk breast cancer like the one who have a familial risk with BRCA gene mutation and those with strong family history of breast carcinoma. The reason being MRI can detect even the early lesions in these patients and help in making the diagnosis at a early stage. Mammography helps as a screening tool in general population and starts at the age of 40 years but it is less sensitive in high risk patients when compared with efficacy of MRI. Role of PET CT in a patient of breast carcinoma is to look for metastasis and not for diagnosis. Only role of USG in case of a breast lesion is to differentiate between a solid and a cystic lesion. USG can not make the diagnosis of breast carcinoma.

choices.text: Breast Imaging Reporting and Data System
Best Imaging Reporting and Data System
Brain Imaging Reporting and Data System
Best Imaging Reporting and Data System

questions.text: BIRADS stands for: (AIIMS Nov 2012)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) BIRADS stands for Breast Imaging Reporting And Data System. It has been stablished to standardize the reporting of the breast lesion by radiologists across the globe . It has seven readings or gradings ranging from grade 0-6

questions.text: All are indicators of malignancy in a mammography except: (AIIMS May 2014)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) In mammography we see the architecture of the tissue, pattern of calcification and characteristic of the mass to arrive at the diagnosis and categorize the lesion as benign or malignant. Nodular calcification or macrocalcifiction is not indicative of breast carcinoma. But if you see speckled margin, attenuated architecture, irregular mass these findings are suggestive of breast carcinoma. Malignant mammographic findings: Ill-defined margin, irregular stellate speculation. Comet tail, high density. Heterogenous mass. Wide halo. Microcalcification (< 0.5 mm size). Architectural distortion. Thickened skin. Thickened cooper ligament, Obiterated subcutaneous retromammary space. New or spiculated masses Clustered microcalcifications in linear or branching array

questions.text: A 55-years old post menopausal woman, on hormone replacement therapy (HRT), present with heaviness in both breasts. A screening mammogram reveals a high density speculated mass with cluster of pleomorphic microcalcification and ipsilateral large axillary lymph nodes. The mass describe here most likely represents:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) In mammography we see the architecture of the tissue, pattern of calcification and characteristic of the mass to arrive at the diagnosis and categorize the lesion as benign or malignant. Malignant mammographic findings: Ill-defined margin, irregular stellate speculation. Comet tail, high density. Heterogenous mass. Wide halo. Microcalcification (< 0.5 mm size). Architectural distortion. Thickened skin. Thickened cooper ligament, Obiterated subcutaneous retromammary space. New or spiculated masses Clustered microcalcifications in linear or branching array

choices.text: Internal mammary lymph nodes are removed

questions.text: True about modified radical mastectomy is: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Modified radical mastectomy is a procedure in which we remove breast tissue along with nipple areola complex, axillary tail, pectoralis fascia along with axillary lymph node stations 1,2 and 3. Modified radical mastectomy can be of 3 types. They are: Auchinclaus: In this we retract pectoralis minor muscle Scanlon: Pectoralis minor muscle is divided to gain access to axillary lymph nodes. Pattey’s: Pectoralis minor muscle is removed to gain access to axillary lymph nodes. Option A is wrong as we do not remove pectoralis major muscle. Option B is wrong as axillary lymphnodes are removed Option D is wrong as we do not remove internal mammary lymph nodes in modified radical mastectomy. So answer is Option C as pectoralis minor muscle can be divided in modified radical mastectomy.

questions.text: Breast conservation surgery includes: (PGI Nov 2015)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A, B, D and E) Brest conservative surgery is defined as a procedure of lumpectomy with 1 cm of resection margin with or without axillary lymph node clearance + Postop Radiotherapy. If lymph nodes are not palpable we need to subject the patient for sentinel lymph node biopsy. Chemotherapy is not a component of Breast conservative surgery.

questions.text: All of the following are removed in radical mastectomy except (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) In radical mastectomy we remove breast tissue along with nipple areola complex, pectoralis major and pectoralis minor muscle and lymph node stations 1,2 and 3 . As supra-clavicular lymphnodes are not removed in radical mastectomy answer to this question is D.

questions.text: Drug used in estrogen dependent breast cancer: (AIIMS May 2015)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Tamoxifen, is a medication that is used to prevent breast cancer in women and treat breast cancer in women and men. It is also being studied for other types of cancer. It has been used for Albright syndrome. Tamoxifen is used for the treatment of both early and advanced estrogen receptor-positive (ER-positive or ER+) breast cancer in pre- and post-menopausal women. In 2006, the large STAR clinical study concluded that raloxifene is also effective in reducing the incidence of breast cancer.

questions.text: Components of QUARTZ except: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Quartz is used in respect to breast conservative surgery and it comprises of Quadrantectomy + Axillary dissection + Radiotherapy. Tamoxifen is not a component of Quartz.

questions.text: Use of tamoxifen for breast cancer can cause all of the following adverse effects, except: (AIIMS May 2015)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Tamoxifen is a SERM (Selective Estrogen Receptor Modulator) so this means that tamoxifen has anti estrogenic effects on breast but it has pro estrogenic effects on uterus and blood. Because of this use of tamoxifen can lead to the formation of thromboembolism and endometrial carcinoma. One of the reasons for using tamoxifen is to prevent the formation of breast carcinoma in the contralateral breast in pre menopausal women.

questions.text: Superolateral boundary of axillary dissection is: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Boundaries of axillary dissection are : Superior and superolateral: Axillary Vein Lateral : Thoracodorsal pedicle Medial : Halstead( Costoclavicular ligament) Inferior: Angular vein

questions.text: A 50-years old female has under gone mastectomy for CA breast. After mastectomy patient is not able to extend adduct and internally rotate the arm. Now supply to which of the following muscle is damaged? (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) The scenario described in the question is the one which shows damage to lattisimus dorsi muscle. It occurs due to injury to Thoracodorsal Nerve. Options A, B and D are not affected after MRM. Another muscle whose function can be affected is serratus anterior muscle due to injury to long thoracic nerve. If this nerve is damaged we can get winging of scapula in the patient.

choices.text: Surrounding normal tissue of tumor is removed

questions.text: In pattey’s mastectomy, the step not done is: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Modified radical mastectomy is a procedure in which we remove breast tissue along with nipple areola complex, axillary tail, pectoralis fascia along with axillary lymph node stations 1,2 and 3. Modified radical mastectomy can be of 3 types. They are: Auchinclaus: In this we retract pectoralis minor muscle Scanlon: Pectoralis minor muscle is divided to gain access to axillary lymph nodes. Pattey’s: Pectoralis minor muscle is removed to gain access to axillary lymph nodes.

questions.text: Malti, a 45-years female patient with a family history of breast carcinoma, showed diffuse microcalcification on mammography. Indraductal carcinoma in situ was seen on biopsy. Most appropriate management is: (AIIMS May 2014)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) For DCIS we usually do not have any lymph node enlargement and for the management of this we do Simple Mastectomy or BCS. There is no role of chemotherapy, although radiotherapy is needed after BCS. Option A is false as quadrantectomy is a component of breast conservative surgery and just doing a quadrantectomy has no role in DCIS Option B is false as we never do radical mastectomy for DCIS, it is an insitu lesion. Option d is false as there is no role of chemotherapy in management of DCIS.

questions.text: For CA breast best chemotherapeutic regimen: (AIIMS May 2015)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Chemotherapy using a first-generation regime such as a 6-monthly cycle of cyclophosphamide, methotrexate and 5-fluorouracil (CMF) will achieve a 25% reduction in the risk of relapse over a 10–15-year period. CMF is no longer considered adequate adjuvant chemotherapy and modern second- and third-generation regimes include an anthracycline (doxorubicin or epirubicin) and the newer agents such as the taxanes. Chemotherapy used to be prescribed only to premenopausal women with a poor prognosis (in whom its effects are likely to be the result, in part, of a chemical castration effect) but it is now also offered to postmenopausal women with poor prognosis disease. Chemotherapy may be considered in node-negative patients if other prognostic factors, such as tumour grade, imply a high risk of recurrence. The effect of combining hormone and chemotherapy is additive, although hormone therapy is started after completion of chemotherapy to reduce side effects.

questions.text: Breast conservative surgery is not indicated in: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) As lobular carcinoma tends to have a multicentric lesion and we can not do breast conservative surgery in multicentric involvement of breast Option A is correct as Breast conservative surgery is an option for young women who want to preserve their breast. Option B and D are correct as DCIS and infiltrating ductal carcinoma does not have a multicentric involvement and can be managed by simple mastectomy or BCS.

questions.text: Absolute contraindication of conservative breast cancer therapy is: (PGI Nov 2014)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B And E) Contraindications for BCT: A patient who may be unreliable with follow-up for radiation therapy (may involve radiation treatment 5 days a week for 5 to 6 weeks); when the extent of disease prevents adequate negative margins; a high tumor-to breast size ratio, which prevents adequate resection without major deformity; persistently positive margins on re-excision; and inability to receive adjuvant radiation (e.g., prior radiation to the chest wall; first- and second-trimester pregnancy in which the delay of radiation to the postpartum state is inappropriate;

questions.text: In breast conservation surgery, the healthy margin excised is typically: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Brest conservative surgery is defined as a procedure of lumpectomy with 1 cm of resection margin with or without axillary lymph node clearance + Post OP Radiotherapy. If lymph nodes are not palpable we need to subject the patient for sentinel lymph node biopsy. Chemotherapy is not a component of Breast conservative surgery. More appropriate answer is 1mm.According to 8th AJCC updates , in breast conservation surgery , the healthy margin excised is typically 1mm.

questions.text: Treatment of hormone dependent fungating carcinoma of breast with secondaries in the lung in a female patient aged 30 years is: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Patient in this clinical scenario has a fungating breast mass which is hormone dependent and has lung metastasis, so as the patient has a fungating breast mass we have to subject the patient to a simple mastectomy to avoid the complications like bleeding from the fungating breast mass or infection. There is no role of doing a radical mastectomy in this patient as patient has already suffered from metastasis. As the tumor is hormone dependant we need to remove the source of hormone so that tumor growth is brought under control and further spread is prevented. So in this patient a simple mastectomy for the fungating breast mass with metastasis along with oophorectomy for removal of the hormonal source is the preferred option. Adrenelectomy has no role in the treatment of breast cancer.

questions.text: Distressing complication after modified radical mastectomy? (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) If during MRM surgeon performs extensive axillary lymph node dissection then patient might develop impaired drainage of lymph from the ipsilateral upper limb leading to lymphedema of that arm and forearm. So of the above options mentioned lymphedema is a distressing complication occurring after MRM. if there is a long standing lymphedema in a patient he might develop lymphangiosarcoma in the limb suffering from lymphoedema. Seroma occurs below the skin flap raised because of fluid accumulating in the dead space and can be managed by draining the seroma.

questions.text: Complication of post mastectomy lymphedema is: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) One of the distressing complication of MRM with extensive axillary dissection is lymphedema, if there is a long standing lymphedema in a patient he might develop lymphangiosarcoma in the limb suffering from lyphoedema. Option A is false as there is no particular predilection of metastasis to occur in a limb suffering from lymphedema, infact common sites of metastasis in a patient of breast cancer is bone and brain. Option B is false because even though recurrence is one of the possibilities after treatment of breast cancer it tends to occur at the operative site rather than in the limb suffering from lymphedema. Option D is also false as pain is not a complication of lymphedema of limb.

questions.text: Pain along medial aspect of arm in a post-mastectomy patient is due to: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Intercostobrachial nerve is the most commonly injured nerve in MRM and if this is injured patient can have pain along the distribution of this nerve that is along the medial aspect of arm.

choices.text: Occurs in 1 of every 3000 pregnant women
MC non-gynecologic malignancy associated with pregnancy
Ductal carcinoma is MC type, accounting for 75-90% breast cancer in pregnancy

questions.text: True about breast cancer in pregnancy (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Option A is correct breast cancer in pregnancy occurs in 1 of every 3000 pregnant women. Option B is correct this makes breast cancer in pregnancy as the most common non-gynecological malignancy associated with pregnancy. Option C is correct as ductal carcinoma is the most common type of breast carcinoma in pregnancy.

questions.text: A 35 years old lactating mother presented with a painful breast lump. Most appropriate initial investigation should be: (AIIMS Nov 2012)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) The most important initial investigation to be done in these patients is USG as this will help us know whether the patient has a cystic or a solid lesion. As one of the most common cause of painful breast lump in 35 year old lactating lady is breast abscess. Mammography will be done after USG if it shows a solid lesion. The main aim of doing mammography in this patient will be to screen the opposite breast for any lesion . MRI and X-ray don’t have any specific role in making diagnosis in this case, X-ray can be used to rule out any metastatic deposits in lungs.

questions.text: Intraoperative sentinel lymph node detection in axilla is done by using: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) SLN biopsy is usually done intra-operatively by using isosulphan blue dye (lymphazurin) or radioactive (Tc-99 labelled sulphur) colloid. Accuracy of detection of SLN biopsy is best when both of the methods are combined. • When radioactive colloid is used, the SLN is detected by gamma-camera • The blue dye colors the afferent lymphatics and SLN, hence aids in the identification. Mammography, MRI and CT scan can not detect lymph nodes intra operatively, they can be helpful preoperatively .

choices.text: Breast mass but no lymph node palpable
Breast lump with palpable axillary node

questions.text: Sentinel lymph node biopsy in carcinoma breast is done if: (Recent Question 2013)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Contraindication of SLN Biopsy in CA Breast 1. Palpable lymphadenopathy 2. Prior axillary surgery, chemotherapy or radiotherapy 3. Multifocal breast cancer 4. Metastatic disease.

questions.text: The flap shown in following figure is based on which vessel ?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) The thoracodorsal artery is the primary source of blood supply to the latissimus dorsi flap. At the time of breast reconstruction, the muscle flap, with or without attached skin, is elevated off of the back and brought around to the front of the chest wall. The main vessels remain attached to the body to ensure proper blood supply to the flap. The LD flap provides soft tissue to allow complete coverage of an underlying implant. Option B. Thoracoacromial vessels supply blood to Pectoralis major myocutaneous flap.

questions.text: A firm 2 to 3 cm mass is palpable in the upper outer quadrant of the right breast of a 52-year-old woman. There are no palpable axillary lymph nodes. A lumpectomy with axillary node dissection is performed and the breast lesion is found to have positive immunohistochemical staining for HER2/neu (ERBB2). Staining for oestrogen and progesterone receptors is negative. Which of the following additional treatment options is most appropriate, based upon these findings?
questions.solution: (c) Transtuzumab This is an infiltrating ductal carcinoma. The lack of Oestrogen Receptor staining suggests a poor response to hormonal therapy with tamoxifen. The positive ERBB2 (HER2/neu) staining suggests that transtuzumab (Herceptin) may be effective.

questions.text: Palpation of breast from outside to inside, then from inside to outside. What is the method of palpation called as
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Option A-Image A is k/s Dial clock method Option B-Image B is k/s vertical stripes method Option C-Image C is k/s Wedges/ Quadrant Option D-Image D is k/s Concentric circlemethod in which palpation of breast is done from outside to inside, then from inside to outside

questions.text: More conspicuous sign of breast cancer is-
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Option A-Puckering is due to involvement of Cooper's ligament.It can occur in other diseases as well. Option B-Circumferential retraction of nipple in breast Cancer is due to involvement of lactiferous ducts.However,slit like nipple retraction is seen in duct ectasia. Option D-Peau De Orange is due to blockage of subdermal Lymphatics by tumour cells.It is a more conspicuous sign of breast cancer.

questions.text: Which of the following does not classify as locally advanced breast cancer?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) 1.Any T4,any N2, any N3 → locally advanced breast cancer 2.T1 T2 T3, EITHER N0/N1→Early breast cancer Option A-Tumor more than 4 cm can be T2,hence it is not considered as locally advanced breast cancer. Option B-Inflammatory breast cancer is T4d,hence considered as locally advanced breast cancer. Option C-Chest wall involvement is T4a,,hence considered as locally advanced breast cancer. Option D-Skin involvement is T4b,hence considered as locally advanced breast cancer.

questions.text: Identify the name of the disease shown here in the breast?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Option A-Pagets disease is insitu ductal cancer,in which whole nipple areola complex gets destroyed. Option B-The given image shows Tender Cord like structures,which is seen in cases of superficial thrombophlebitis of breast.This condition is known as Mondor’disease. No specific treatment is required. Rest, hot fomentation, anti-inflammatory are the mainstay of treatment. Option C-There is nothing known as Red manhood in breast. Option D-Tietz syndrome is the costochondritis of costal cartilage,therefore, patient complaints of mastalgia, problem under the breast.

questions.text: Tamoxifen is given for breast cancer. which complication is associated with its use:-
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Tamoxifen is a selective Estrogen Receptor Modulator , approved for the treatment of Estrogen Receptor positive breast cancer. It is used only in premenopausal women for 5 years in low risk patients and for 10 years in patients with a high risk of relapse ( node- positive , tumor>5cm , lymphovascular invasion). It is also known to reduce the incidence of secondary primary breast cancer in the contralateral breast. Tamoxifen increases the risk of Endometrial cancer in post-menopausal women , hence aromatase Inhibitors are used in post-menopausal women. Tamoxifen increases the risk of Endometrial cancer by 1-2% . The benefits of tamoxifen in breast cancer outweighs the risk of Endometrial cancer.

questions.text: A lady with a breast lump of 6x6cm in upper outer quadrant with one ipsilateral enlarged axillary lymph node. Which investigation is not needed A. PET scan B. B/L breast mammogram C. Tru cut from breast mass D. Tru cut from lymph node
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) The triple assessment method is used to evaluate a patient who presents with a breast lump or has any symptoms suspicious of CA breast . Triple assessment of breast lump includes the following 3 parameters: - Clinical assessment: Clinical history and physical examination of the lump - Radiological examination: USG or mammogram or both - Cytological examination: FNAC or core biopsy of the lump.(not from lymph node). This is the most commonly used method as the PPV of this combination is 99.99%. PET scan and Lymph node biopsy is not a part of the triple assessment method.

questions.text: A 60 year old lady has a massive enlargement of breast over 30 days, it is mobile over chest wall with local rise of temperature.What is the most likely cause?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) In the given scenario of 60 YEAR OLD patient, the rapid onset of the disease and the examination findings are suggestive of Inflammatory carcinoma of the breast . - Inflammatory breast cancer is the most aggressive subtype of breast cancer . It mimics acute mastitis . The hallmark of Inflammatory breast carcinoma is the diffuse tumor involvement of the dermal lymphatics within the breast and the overlying skin , often without a discrete underlying tumor mass (peau d' orange appearance). The patient presents with rapidly progressive swelling of the breast, warmth , erythema and edema . A breast lump may or may not be present . - A diagnosis of Inflammatory breast carcinoma should be suspected when a patient with rapidly progressive swelling with Inflammatory skin changes does not respond to antibiotics. The imaging features with ultrasound and a mammogram is non-specific because of underlying erythema and edema . A biopsy should be done to confirm the diagnosis.

questions.text: A female patient presented to hospital with right breast lump. Lump was located in UOQ with no axillary lymph nodes. Mammography revealed BIRADS 4. Patient underwent breast conservation surgery. Final HPE revealed high grade DCIS. What is the next step?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) In case of DCIS,we've to calculate VNPI(van nuys prognostic index),if the score comes between:- 4 TO 6 POINTS → WIDE LOCAL EXCISION 7 TO 9 → WIDE LOCAL EXCISION WITH RADIOTHERAPY 10 TO 12 → SIMPLE MASTECTOMY. Since age,size of lesion and margin is not given.so we cannot calculate score fully.but HIGH GRADE DCIS will give it 3 POINTS.so roughly the score will lie between 7-9,hence,radiotherapy should be given.

questions.text: A 32 year female patient is on Tamoxifen after a breast cancer surgery. For around 5 years she was on Tamoxifen. When will she stop Tamoxifen if she wants to conceive?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) TAMOXIFEN IDEALLY SHOULD BE STOPPED MINIMUM 2 MONTHS BEFORE CONCEIVING.So,the best answer here out of the given options is 1 month before conceiving.

questions.text: Match the following?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Thyroid is a superficial structure and can be biopsied by USG guided biopsy method. Breast biopsy is done by Tru cut biopsy. Lymph node usually can be excised as a whole,hence,Excisional biopsy will be done. Marjolin ulcer can be sampled by Incisional biopsy.

questions.text: Not routinely used in the diagnosis of breast cancer?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) The triple assessment method is used to evaluate a patient who presents with a breast lump or has any symptoms suspicious of CA breast. PET scan is not a part of the triple assessment method. Triple assessment of breast lump includes the following 3 parameters: - Clinical assessment: Clinical history and physical examination of the lump Radiological examination: USG or mammogram or both Cytological examination: FNAC or core biopsy of the lump . This is the most commonly used method as the PPV of this combination is 99.99%.

questions.text: All are contra-indications of breast conservation surgery except?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Absolute contraindications of BCT : - 1.Pregnancy 2.Persistently positive margins 3.Multicentric lumps 4.Diffuse microcalcificatiom 5.Extensive DCIS 6.Inflammatory breast cancer Relative contraindications of BCT: - 1.Active SLE 2.Large lump to breast ratio ( > 5 cm size lump) 3.Known or suspected genetic predisposition to breast cancer (i.e, BRCA-1 , BRCA-2) , Li-fraumeni syndrome (P-53 mutation) 4.Multifocal disease 5.Prior Radiotherapy to chest wall or breast

questions.text: Which of the following steps are done in Breast Conservation Surgery? 1. Wide local excision 2. Axillary node dissection can be done 3. Frozen section (biopsy) can be done during surgery 4. Post-operative radiotherapy is optional
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Breast Conservation Surgery or lumpectomy is a surgical approach used to treat breast cancer while preserving the breast tissue. It typically involves 2 components:- 1. Lumpectomy- with 1 mm margin. 2. Radiation therapy is recommended after lumpectomy(it's not optional) to destroy any remaining cancer cells and reduce the risk of local recurrence. 3.Axillary node dissection can be done as well frozen section (biopsy) can be done during surgery.

questions.text: Most important prognostic factor for CA Breast
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Lymph Node (LN) Status Lymph node involvement is the strongest independent prognostic factor in breast cancer. The number of involved axillary lymph nodes directly correlates with the risk of recurrence and overall survival. While distant metastasis (option B) is crucial for staging and indicates a poorer overall prognosis, it is more reflective of current stage rather than a modifiable or early prognostic indicator. Tumor size (option C) and hormone receptor status (option D) also matter, but they are secondary to lymph node status in terms of prognosis.
